original_text: To address the vertical displacement estimation of conventional pile groups subjected to mechanical loads, various numerical and analytical methods have been proposed. These methods include the finite element method [e.g., 2,3], the boundary element method [e.g., 4,5], the finite difference method [e.g., 6], the interaction factor method [e.g., 7,8–11], the equivalent pier and raft methods [e.g., 12–14], and the settlement ratio method [e.g., 15]. The finite element method, while providing the most rigorous and exhaustive representation of the pile group-related problem, is generally computationally expensive and considered mainly a research tool rather than a design tool. Conversely, the versatility of simplified (approximate) methods, such as the interaction factor approach that allows capturing the (e.g., vertical) displacements of any general pile group by the analysis of the displacement interaction between two identical piles and by the use of the elastic principle of superposition of effects, makes them attractive as design tools because they allow for the use of expedient parametric studies under various design conditions.
original_translation: Para abordar la estimación del desplazamiento vertical de grupos de pilotes convencionales sometidos a cargas mecánicas, se han propuesto varios métodos numéricos y analíticos. Estos métodos incluyen el método de elementos finitos [por ejemplo, 2,3], el método de elementos de contorno [por ejemplo, 4,5], el método de diferencias finitas [por ejemplo, 6], el método de factor de interacción [por ejemplo, 7,8–11], los métodos de pilote y losa equivalentes [por ejemplo, 12–14], y el método de relación de asentamiento [por ejemplo, 15]. El método de elementos finitos, si bien proporciona la representación más rigurosa y exhaustiva del problema relacionado con el grupo de pilotes, generalmente es computacionalmente costoso y se considera principalmente una herramienta de investigación en lugar de una herramienta de diseño. Por otro lado, la versatilidad de métodos simplificados (aproximados), como el enfoque del factor de interacción que permite capturar los desplazamientos (por ejemplo, verticales) de cualquier grupo general de pilotes mediante el análisis de la interacción de desplazamientos entre dos pilotes idénticos y mediante el uso del principio elástico de superposición de efectos, los hace atractivos como herramientas de diseño porque permiten el uso de estudios paramétricos expeditos bajo diversas condiciones de diseño.
original_sentences: To address the vertical displacement estimation of conventional pile groups subjected to mechanical loads, various numerical and analytical methods have been proposed.

These methods include the finite element method [e.g., 2,3], the boundary element method [e.g., 4,5], the finite difference method [e.g., 6], the interaction factor method [e.g., 7,8–11], the equivalent pier and raft methods [e.g., 12–14], and the settlement ratio method [e.g., 15].

The finite element method, while providing the most rigorous and exhaustive representation of the pile group-related problem, is generally computationally expensive and considered mainly a research tool rather than a design tool.

Conversely, the versatility of simplified (approximate) methods, such as the interaction factor approach that allows capturing the (e.g., vertical) displacements of any general pile group by the analysis of the displacement interaction between two identical piles and by the use of the elastic principle of superposition of effects, makes them attractive as design tools because they allow for the use of expedient parametric studies under various design conditions.

original_annotated_sentences: To address the vertical displacement estimation of conventional pile groups subjected to mechanical loads, various numerical and analytical methods have been proposed.

These methods include the finite element method [e.g., 2,3], the boundary element method [e.g., 4,5], the
finite difference method
[e.g., 6], the interaction factor method [e.g., 7,8–11], the equivalent pier and raft methods [e.g., 12–14], and the settlement ratio method [e.g., 15].

The finite element method, while providing the most rigorous and exhaustive representation of the pile group-related problem, is generally computationally expensive and considered mainly a research tool rather than a design tool.

Conversely, the versatility of simplified (approximate) methods, such as the interaction factor approach that allows capturing the (e.g., vertical) displacements of any general pile group by the analysis of the displacement interaction between two identical piles and by the use of the elastic principle of superposition of effects, makes them attractive as design tools because they allow for the use of expedient parametric studies under various design conditions.

vertical displacement estimation of conventional pile groups subjected to mechanical loads
, various numerical and analytical methods have been proposed.

These methods include the finite element method [e.g., 2,3], the boundary element method [e.g., 4,5], the finite difference method [e.g., 6], the interaction factor method [e.g., 7,8–11], the equivalent pier and raft methods [e.g., 12–14], and the settlement ratio method [e.g., 15].

The finite element method, while providing the most rigorous and exhaustive representation of the pile group-related problem, is generally computationally expensive and considered mainly a research tool rather than a design tool.

Conversely, the versatility of simplified (approximate) methods, such as the interaction factor approach that allows capturing the (e.g., vertical) displacements of any general pile group by the analysis of the displacement interaction between two identical piles and by the use of the elastic principle of superposition of effects, makes them attractive as design tools because they allow for the use of expedient parametric studies under various design conditions.
original_annotated_samples:
To address the
vertical displacement estimation of conventional pile groups subjected to mechanical loads
, various numerical and analytical methods have been proposed.

Para abordar la estimación de desplazamiento
vertical de grupos de pilotes convencionales sometidos a cargas mecánicas
, se han propuesto varios métodos numéricos y analíticos.
vertical displacement estimation of conv.translated_text:
Para abordar la estimación de desplazamiento
vertical de grupos de pilotes convencionales sometidos a cargas mecánicas
, se han propuesto varios métodos numéricos y analíticos. Estos métodos incluyen el método de elementos finitos [por ejemplo, 2,3], el método de elementos de contorno [por ejemplo, 4,5], el método de diferencias finitas [por ejemplo, 6], el método de factor de interacción [por ejemplo, 7,8–11], los métodos de pilote y losa equivalentes [por ejemplo, 12–14], y el método de relación de asentamiento [por ejemplo, 15]. El método de elementos finitos, si bien proporciona la representación más rigurosa y exhaustiva del problema relacionado con el grupo de pilotes, generalmente es computacionalmente costoso y se considera principalmente una herramienta de investigación en lugar de una herramienta de diseño. Por otro lado, la versatilidad de métodos simplificados (aproximados), como el enfoque del factor de interacción que permite capturar los desplazamientos (por ejemplo, verticales) de cualquier grupo general de pilotes mediante el análisis de la interacción de desplazamientos entre dos pilotes idénticos y mediante el uso del principio elástico de superposición de efectos, los hace atractivos como herramientas de diseño porque permiten el uso de estudios paramétricos expeditos bajo diversas condiciones de diseño.
